summary: antis want everything to be daenerys’ fault so badly that they truly believe that the wight hunt was all her fault, because...
body:
antis want everything to be daenerys’ fault so badly that they truly believe that the wight hunt was all her fault, because she’s mad and couldn’t understand the real threat beyond the wall. because she’s too stubborn to take her eyes off anything that isn’t the pretty throne she wants so badly. they totally bypass the reality that Jon would’ve needed to go beyond the wall to capture a wight regardless of daenerys. If daenerys wasn’t in Westeros, jon would’ve still been hailed KITN, he still would’ve gotten that letter from cersei telling him to bend the knee, and he would’ve still had to travel beyond the wall to capture a wight to convince cersei that the threat beyond the wall is real.


The audience ofcourse knows about the threat beyond the wall because from the very first scene we see what they’re capable of. we know they’re the biggest threat because we’ve been following jons storyline at the wall. but daenerys doesn’t know squat about this night king. How could she? They get angry at dany for not believing this supposed night king and army of the dead when she’s been exiled in Essos since she was born, abused by her brother, moved place to place to avoid assassination attempts, sold and practically a sex slave, chained, betrayed by those she loves and doing her very best to save people from terrible fates this whole time! How could she know about the night king. She’s not going to just believe some northerner who comes up to her as soon as she lands in dragonstone and asks for her help, it could be a folly from cersei herself, she has no clue. She doesn’t know Jon Snow, just that he’s the son of the man who helped dethrone her family. Even her advisers have said “you must allow them their flights of fancy, it’s dreary in the north,” her advisors don’t even believe this threat is real, why would she?


Once daenerys gets the message from Jon telling her that they’re surrounded, she still hasn’t seen this army of the dead and flies out to save him anyways! she hasn’t even seen this threat but now she knows and trusts Jon enough to know he wouldn’t lie to her. And once she had seen the night king, she completely 100% drops her fight with cersei and makes a truce to stay nuetral until the threat in the north is dealt with. As daenerys says, “My dragon died so we could be here. If we’re here for nothing, then he died for nothing.” She literally lost a dragon. A dragon. Something she values and views as her own child. She continues to sail North with Jon in hope that her aid will help defeat the night king.


Cersei on the other hand sees the wight, sees what they can do, sees how they can’t be killed with regular steel and still tricks Jon and Daenerys into thinking she will help them when in actuality she sent for more armies to keep her position of power.


But it’s daenerys who is the mad queen? It’s daenerys fault that the wight hunt happened? Sure.

reblog.comment:
antis want everything to be daenerys’ fault so badly that they truly believe that the wight hunt was all her fault, because she’s mad and couldn’t understand the real threat beyond the wall. because she’s too stubborn to take her eyes off anything that isn’t the pretty throne she wants so badly. they totally bypass the reality that Jon would’ve needed to go beyond the wall to capture a wight regardless of daenerys. If daenerys wasn’t in Westeros, jon would’ve still been hailed KITN, he still would’ve gotten that letter from cersei telling him to bend the knee, and he would’ve still had to travel beyond the wall to capture a wight to convince cersei that the threat beyond the wall is real.


The audience ofcourse knows about the threat beyond the wall because from the very first scene we see what they’re capable of. we know they’re the biggest threat because we’ve been following jons storyline at the wall. but daenerys doesn’t know squat about this night king. How could she? They get angry at dany for not believing this supposed night king and army of the dead when she’s been exiled in Essos since she was born, abused by her brother, moved place to place to avoid assassination attempts, sold and practically a sex slave, chained, betrayed by those she loves and doing her very best to save people from terrible fates this whole time! How could she know about the night king. She’s not going to just believe some northerner who comes up to her as soon as she lands in dragonstone and asks for her help, it could be a folly from cersei herself, she has no clue. She doesn’t know Jon Snow, just that he’s the son of the man who helped dethrone her family. Even her advisers have said “you must allow them their flights of fancy, it’s dreary in the north,” her advisors don’t even believe this threat is real, why would she?


Once daenerys gets the message from Jon telling her that they’re surrounded, she still hasn’t seen this army of the dead and flies out to save him anyways! she hasn’t even seen this threat but now she knows and trusts Jon enough to know he wouldn’t lie to her. And once she had seen the night king, she completely 100% drops her fight with cersei and makes a truce to stay nuetral until the threat in the north is dealt with. As daenerys says, “My dragon died so we could be here. If we’re here for nothing, then he died for nothing.” She literally lost a dragon. A dragon. Something she values and views as her own child. She continues to sail North with Jon in hope that her aid will help defeat the night king.


Cersei on the other hand sees the wight, sees what they can do, sees how they can’t be killed with regular steel and still tricks Jon and Daenerys into thinking she will help them when in actuality she sent for more armies to keep her position of power.


But it’s daenerys who is the mad queen? It’s daenerys fault that the wight hunt happened? Sure.

antis want everything to be daenerys’ fault so badly that they truly believe that the wight hunt was all her fault, because she’s mad and couldn’t understand the real threat beyond the wall. because she’s too stubborn to take her eyes off anything that isn’t the pretty throne she wants so badly. they totally bypass the reality that Jon would’ve needed to go beyond the wall to capture a wight regardless of daenerys. The audience ofcourse knows about the threat beyond the wall because from the very first scene we see what they’re capable of. we know they’re the biggest threat because we’ve been following jons storyline at the wall. but daenerys doesn’t know squat about this night king. How could she? They get angry at dany for not believing this supposed night king and army of the dead when she’s been exiled in Essos since she was born, abused by her brother, moved place to place to avoid assassination attempts, sold and practically a sex slave, chained, betrayed by those she loves and doing her very best to save people from terrible fates this whole time! How could she know about the night king. She’s not going to just believe some northerner who comes up to her as soon as she lands in dragonstone and asks for her help, it could be a folly from cersei herself, she has no clue. She doesn’t know Jon Snow, just that he’s the son of the man who helped dethrone her family. Even her advisers have said “you must allow them their flights of fancy, it’s dreary in the north,” her advisors don’t even believe this threat is real, why would she?


Once daenerys gets the message from Jon telling her that they’re surrounded, she still hasn’t seen this army of the dead and flies out to save him anyways! she hasn’t even seen this threat but now she knows and trusts Jon enough to know he wouldn’t lie to her. summary:
Serious Jon Snow Question 
If Viserys was still alive somewhere and he and Jon ever came face to face, would he do to Viserys...
body:
Serious Jon Snow Question

If Viserys was still alive somewhere and he and Jon ever came face to face, would he do to Viserys what he did to Ramsay Bolton?

Spoiler alert, he totes would, and I would pay to see it.

Now heir of the realm entire

title: Parallels
body:
Dany got pulled up by the people.

Jon had to fight his way from the ground and got himself all the way up.

There’s something more that I’m missing, but something about this parallel and the difference between these two doesn’t sit right with me.

reblog.comment:
Dany got pulled up by the people.

Jon had to fight his way from the ground and got himself all the way up.

There’s something more that I’m missing, but something about this parallel and the difference between these two doesn’t sit right with me.

trail.content_raw:
Dany got pulled up by the people.

Jon had to fight his way from the ground and got himself all the way up.

There’s something more that I’m missing, but something about this parallel and the difference between these two doesn’t sit right with me.
trail.content:
Dany got pulled up by the people.

Jon had to fight his way from the ground and got himself all the way up.

There’s something more that I’m missing, but something about this parallel and the difference between these two doesn’t sit right with me.

body: Wait, so you mean to tell me that Jon Snow is in love with Sansa Stark but as his first lay after being brought back FROM THE DEAD, he chose a woman he supposedly loathes and is just planning on betraying anyway? The first woman he sleeps with after literally rising again from the dead, is a woman who means NOTHING to him??? All I gotta say to that is:

blog.name: stormcloudrising
blog.title: Storm Cloud Rising
blog.description: Theories and analysis of my favorite shows, books, life and anything of interest

summary: Florian and Jonquil, Jon and Sansa and the Blue Winter Rose
title: Florian and Jonquil, Jon and Sansa and the Blue Winter Rose
body:
October 11, 2018

This is a brief preview of a section of the  essay about Florian and Jonquil that I’m currently writing.  This topic has been on my list of metas to write for a while and there are about 3 - 4 others I had plans to write before this one. However, the release of the Fire and Blood excerpt that dealt with Good Queen Alysanne’s visit to the North was the impetus for me to move this topic to the top of the list.  This is because of the mention of Jonquil Darke, the Scarlet Shadow provided some clues to the original Jonquil and I decided now was a good time to get to it while things were percolating in my brain..

I am super excited to read the Alysanne chapter in its entirety when the book comes out next month because I’m sure it will provide many additional clues to the storylines for Sansa and many of the other characters.  I’m additionally glad George released the excerpt because as I said, it made me start on my Florian and Jonquil essay and it was in doing some research on the subject that I got caught up in readingThe Hedge Knight again.  

I’ve used quotes from the book here and there in some of my essays but I haven’t read the story itself in a while.  The Dunk and Egg novellas are some of the most enjoyable stories of the series and I highly recommend reading them.  And so it  was as I was sitting on the train last night and reading The Hedge Knight during my commute that a clue to one of my theories jumped out at me from one of the drawings.

If you have read my Of Stark and the Glass Menagerie essay, you are aware of my theory that the famous Blue Winter Rose is actually the jonquil flower.  There are several reasons for this theory not the least being that the modern rose is a cultivated flower that did not exist during the middle ages or more ancient times.  However, the jonquil flower did and it was considered by many to be a wild rose.  In fact many scholars believe that the narcissus-jonquilla is actually the Rose of Sharon flower referenced in the famous biblical poem, Song of Solomon.  Here is the passage in question.

Female

I am the rose of Sharon,
and the lily of the valleys.

Male

As the lily among thorns,
so is my love among the daughters.

It is my theory that while the blue winter rose Dany saw in the chink in the wall tips to Lyanna as Jon’s mother, in the story proper, it is more indicative of Sansa Stark, her importance to the story; connection to Jon Snow; and their future relationship.

I think that hints of this relationship is there in many of the ancient tales because just as George uses the story proper to provide clues to the stories of the past, he also  uses the tales and songs of times past as hints to the current story.  He also makes heavy use of comparative mythology to tell his story and this is a topic I will cover a bit more in the full essay.  One such ancient tale that I think Martin uses to strongly denote things to come in the books is the story about Florian and Jonquil.

Any how, there I was last night sitting on the train, getting lost in the adventures of Dunk and Egg when suddenly a drawing of Florian and Jonquil jump out at me.  I’ve seen this drawing a million times and yet there is something about the image that I never noticed until last night.  

Those of you familiar with the Dunk and Egg stories will know that black and white line drawings are included throughout.  These drawings showcase various scenes from the books.  The image of which I speak appears in the chapter where Dunk speaks to Tanselle Too-Tall for the first time.  It comes up just after Dunk and Egg have watched her perform her puppet show about Florian and Jonquil.

As I stated, the drawings in the books always showcase the dialogue or description of the scene in which they appear and I am positive that George approved all of them in advance.  During the puppet show, Florian is described as kneeling to Jonquil and that is the scene shown in the drawing. Here is the image in question.

 Did you see it?

Look at what is laying on the ground in the scene.  A FREAKING ROSE!  Now believe me when I tell you that at no point during the puppet show and Dunk’s mental voice over of what is happening is a rose mentioned.  And yet, there is one shown in the drawing.  Why is it there?  To me, this absolutely shows that the rose connects to the story of Florian and Jonquil.  There are two iconic flowers in the story and how interesting is it that both connect to daughters of House Stark.  

When I refer to the jonquil as an iconic flower in the story it is not to say that the actual flower appears in the tale.  What I mean is that jonquil is the name of a flower and in the story it is associated with one person only and that is Sansa Stark.  So what do you think the odds are that two flowers strongly associated with the daughters of the most important family in the story are different totally different sweet smelling blooms?  I say little to none.  You can look at it as either the jonquil is the blue winter rose or the blue winter rose is the jonquil flower.  Same difference!

So we come to the end of my preview chapter.  In the full essay series, I will be piecing together the many hints in the story that tie Florian to Jon and Jonquil to Sansa and their future story tightly together.  If you look closely, you will see that George has actually dropped a lot of clues about the story of Florian and Jonquil.  I will also be discussing Martin’s use of comparative mythology because it’s really interesting and I think a very important part of the story.

blog.name: chitowngirl-12
blog.title: Chicago Diva
blog.description: I'm a fan of Jon, the North, and the Starks.  Not a Jonsa, but an ally because they are nice, rational people unlike other parts of GOT fandom that will remain nameless.  (Apparently I'm also a sexist crazy person for having bad, ungood opinions about Daenerys Targaryen!  And I also set up alts and post anonymous comments and talk to myself on AO3...  Sarc off.  Yeah, fandom is pissing me off right now.)

summary: Daenerys fans keep telling me that Jon giving up the North after she agreed to help him with no strings attached was an...
body:
Daenerys fans keep telling me that Jon giving up the North after she agreed to help him with no strings attached was an awesomely awesome decision.  But I’ve heard no valid strategic or political reasons why this is a good thing.  The only thing that I’ve heard is Dany deserves absolute power because she is helping.

Still waiting for a better explanation.

reblog.comment:

Still waiting for a better explanation.
